question: Question 1 An ideal p-n junction germanium diode has a reverse saturation current of [latex]10 \mu \mathrm{~A}[/latex] at 300 K . The voltage (in Volts, rounded off to two decimal places) to be applied across the junction to get a forward bias current of 100 mA at 300 K is __________ . (Consider the Boltzmann constant [latex]\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{B}}=1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K}[/latex] and the charge of an electron [latex]\mathrm{e}=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}[/latex].)
solution:
[latex] I = I_s \left( e^{\frac{eV}{k_BT}} - 1 \right) [/latex] Where:
[latex] I = 100\ \text{mA} = 0.1\ \text{A} [/latex] [latex] I_s = 10\ \mu\text{A} = 10 \times 10^{-6}\ \text{A} [/latex] [latex] T = 300\ \text{K} [/latex] [latex] e = 1.6 \times 10^{-19}\ \text{C} [/latex] [latex] k_B = 1.38 \times 10^{-23}\ \text{J/K} [/latex] Approximate since [latex] I \gg I_s [/latex], so:
[latex] I \approx I_s e^{\frac{eV}{k_BT}} [/latex] Taking natural logarithm on both sides:
[latex] \frac{eV}{k_BT} = \ln\left(\frac{I}{I_s}\right) [/latex] [latex] V = \frac{k_BT}{e} \ln\left(\frac{I}{I_s}\right) [/latex] Now plug in the values:
[latex] \frac{k_BT}{e} = \frac{1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 300}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} = 0.025875\ \text{V} [/latex] [latex] \ln\left(\frac{0.1}{10 \times 10^{-6}}\right) = \ln(10000) = \ln(10^4) = 4 \ln(10) \approx 4 \times 2.3026 = 9.2104 [/latex] So,
[latex] V = 0.025875 \times 9.2104 \approx 0.2382\ \text{V} [/latex]

question: Question 2 The electron mobility [latex]\mu_{\mathrm{n}}[/latex] in a non-degenerate germanium semiconductor at 300 K is [latex]0.38 \mathrm{~m}^{2} / \mathrm{Vs}[/latex]. The electron diffusivity [latex]\mathrm{D}_{\mathrm{n}}[/latex] at 300 K (in [latex]\mathrm{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{s}[/latex], rounded off to the nearest integer) is __________ . (Consider the Boltzmann constant [latex]\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{B}}=1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K}[/latex] and the charge of an electron [latex]\mathrm{e}=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}[/latex].)
solution: Given: [latex]\mu_{\mathrm{n}}=0.38 \mathrm{~m}^{2} / \mathrm{V}[/latex]-sec at [latex]\mathrm{T}=300^{\circ} \mathrm{K}[/latex] As [latex]D_{n}=\mu_{n} V_{T}=\mu_{n} \cdot \frac{T}{11600}[/latex] At [latex]300^{\circ} \mathrm{K}, \mathrm{D}_{\mathrm{n}}=0.38 \times \frac{300}{11600}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \mathrm{D}_{\mathrm{n}}=98.26 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The intrinsic carrier concentration of a semiconductor is [latex]2.5 \times 10^{16} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] at 300 K. If the electron and hole mobilities are [latex]0.15 \mathrm{~m}^{2} / \mathrm{Vs}[/latex] and [latex]0.05 \mathrm{~m}^{2} / \mathrm{Vs}[/latex], respectively, then the intrinsic resistivity of the semiconductor (in [latex]\mathrm{k} \Omega . \mathrm{m}[/latex] ) at 300 K is __________ . (Charge of an electron [latex]\mathrm{e}=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}[/latex].)
solution: We are given: [latex]n_i = 2.5 \times 10^{16}\ \text{m}^{-3}[/latex] [latex]\mu_n = 0.15\ \text{m}^2/\text{V?s}[/latex] [latex]\mu_p = 0.05\ \text{m}^2/\text{V?s}[/latex] [latex]e = 1.6 \times 10^{-19}\ \text{C}[/latex] The intrinsic conductivity is given by: [latex]\sigma = e \cdot n_i \cdot (\mu_n + \mu_p)[/latex] Substitute values: [latex]\sigma = 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \cdot 2.5 \times 10^{16} \cdot (0.15 + 0.05)[/latex] [latex]\sigma = 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \cdot 2.5 \times 10^{16} \cdot 0.20[/latex] First calculate: [latex]1.6 \times 2.5 = 4.0[/latex] [latex]4.0 \times 0.20 = 0.8[/latex] So: [latex]\sigma = 0.8 \times 10^{-3} = 8 \times 10^{-4}\ \text{S/m}[/latex] Then resistivity is: [latex]\rho = \frac{1}{\sigma} = \frac{1}{8 \times 10^{-4}} = 1250\ \Omega \cdot \text{m} = 1.25\ \text{k}\Omega \cdot \text{m}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Which of the following can be used as an n-type dopant for silicon? Select the correct option(s).
solution: Silicon is a group-IV element. To create an n-type semiconductor, we dope silicon with a group-V element, which donates an extra electron (free carrier). Now, let's evaluate each dopant: (A) Arsenic - Group V element [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] n-type dopant (B) Boron - Group III element [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] p-type dopant (C) Gallium - Group III element [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] p-type dopant (D) Phosphorous - Group V element [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] n-type dopant

question: Question 5 The ideal BJT in the circuit given below is biased in the active region with a [latex]\beta[/latex] of 100. If [latex]\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{B}}[/latex] is [latex]10 \mu \mathrm{~A}[/latex], then [latex]\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{CE}}[/latex] (in Volts, rounded off to two decimal places) is __________ .
solution:
Given [latex]\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{B}}=10 \mu \mathrm{~A}[/latex] and [latex]\beta=100[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{E}}=(\beta+1) \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{B}}=(101) 10 \mu=1.01 \mathrm{~mA}[/latex]

Applying KVL at output loop, we have [latex]10=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{E}}(5 \mathrm{k})+\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{CE}}+\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{E}}(3 \mathrm{k})[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{CE}}=10-\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{E}}(8 \mathrm{k})=10-1.01 \mathrm{~m}(8 \mathrm{k})=1.92 \mathrm{~V}[/latex]

question:
Question 17 A p-type semiconductor with zero electric field is under illumination (low level
injection) in steady state condition. Excess minority carrier density is zero at [latex] x=\pm 2l_n[/latex], where [latex] l_n=10^{-4} cm[/latex] is the diffusion length of electrons. Assume
electronic charge, [latex] q=-1.6 \times 10^{-19}C[/latex]. The profiles of photo-generation rate of
carriers and the recombination rate of excess minority carriers (R) are shown. Under
these conditions, the magnitude of the current density due to the photo-generated
electrons at [latex] x=+2l_n[/latex] is _________ [latex] mA/cm^2[/latex]
 (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
Given, [latex] \begin{aligned}
\delta _n(x)&=R\tau _n=10^{20}e^{-|x|/l_n}\cdot \tau _n\\
\delta (l_n)&=10^{20}e^{-1}\tau _n \;\;\;...(i)\\
for \;\; l_n\leq x\leq 2l_n
\end{aligned}[/latex] Continuity equation is given by [latex] D_n\frac{\partial^2 \delta _n}{\partial x^2}+G-R \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] G and R both are zero - for
[latex] [l_n\leq x\leq 2l_n][/latex] Hence Equation (i) reduced to 
[latex] D_n \frac{\partial^n \delta _n }{\partial x^2}=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \delta _n(x)=Ax+B[/latex] For calculating A and B we use Boundary
condition [latex] \delta _n(2l_n)=0\; \Rightarrow A=\frac{-B}{2l_n}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \delta _n(x)=\frac{-B}{2l_n}x+B=B\left [ 1-\frac{x}{2l_n} \right ] \;\;\;...(iii)[/latex] At 
[latex]x=l_n [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
 10^{20}e^{-1}\tau _n&=B\left [ 1-\frac{l_n}{2l_n} \right ] \\ 
 B&= 2 \times 10^{20}e^{-1}\tau _n\\ 
\therefore \; \delta _n(x) &=2 \times 10^{20} e^{-1}\tau _n\left [ 1-\frac{x}{2l_n} \right ]
\end{aligned} [/latex] for [latex]l_n \leq x \leq 2l_n [/latex] Electron diffusion current density is given by
[latex] |J_n|_{diff}=qD_n\frac{d\eta }{dx}=qD_n \times 2 \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1} \times \tau _n\left [ 0-\frac{1}{2l_n} \right ][/latex] [latex] =\frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times l_n ^2 \times 2 \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1}}{2l_n}[/latex] [latex]=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times l_n  \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1} [/latex] [latex] =1.6 \times 10 \times 1 \times 10^{-4} \times e^{-1}[/latex] [latex] =0.59mA/cm^2[/latex]

question:
Question 19 An ideal MOS capacitor (p-type semiconductor) is shown in the figure. The MOS
capacitor is under strong inversion with [latex] V_G=2V[/latex]. The corresponding inversion
charge density [latex] Q_{IN}[/latex] is [latex] 2.2\mu C/cm^2[/latex]. Assume oxide capacitance per unit area as [latex] C_{OX}=1.7\mu F/cm^2[/latex]. For [latex] V_G=4V[/latex], the value of [latex] Q_{IN}[/latex] is ______[latex] \mu C/cm^2[/latex] (rounded off
to one decimal place).

Question 20 In a non-degenerate bulk semiconductor with electron density [latex]n=10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex], the
value of [latex]E_C-E_{Fn}=200meV[/latex], where [latex]E_C[/latex] and [latex]E_{Fn}[/latex] denote the bottom of the
conduction band energy and electron Fermi level energy, respectively. Assume
thermal voltage as 26 meV and the intrinsic carrier concentration is [latex]10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex]. For [latex]n=0.5 \times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex], the closest approximation of the value of ([latex]E_C-E_{Fn}[/latex]), among
the given options, is ______.
solution:
Here we have to find the value of
[latex]E_c-E_{fn}[/latex] As we know, [latex]E_C-E_F=kT \ln\left ( \frac{N_c}{n} \right ) \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex]E_C-E_{F1}=kT \ln\left ( \frac{N_c}{n_1} \right ) \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] [latex]E_C-E_{F2}=kT \ln\left ( \frac{N_c}{n_2} \right ) \;\;\;...(iii)[/latex] Equation (ii) - Equation (iii) [latex](E_C-E_{F1})-(E_C-E_{F2})=kT \ln \left ( \frac{\frac{N_c}{n_1}}{\frac{N_c}{n_2}} \right )=kT \ln \frac{n_2}{n_1}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow 200meV-(E_C-E_{F2})=26meV \times \ln \left ( \frac{0.5 \times 10^{16}}{1 \times 10^{16}} \right )[/latex] [latex] 200meV-(E_C-E_{F2})=+26meV \ln (0.5)=-18[/latex] [latex](E_C-E_{F2})=200+8=218meV[/latex]

question:
Question 21 Consider a long rectangular bar of direct bandgap p-type semiconductor. The
equilibrium hole density is [latex]10^{17}cm^{-3}[/latex] and the intrinsic carrier concentration is [latex]10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex]. Electron and hole diffusion lengths are [latex]2\mu m[/latex]and [latex]1\mu m[/latex], respectively.
The left side of the bar ([latex]x=0[/latex]) is uniformly illuminated with a laser having photon
energy greater than the bandgap of the semiconductor. Excess electron-hole pairs
are generated ONLY at [latex]x=0[/latex] because of the laser. The steady state electron density
at [latex]x=0[/latex] is [latex]10^{14}cm^{-3}[/latex]
 due to laser illumination. Under these conditions and ignoring
electric field, the closest approximation (among the given options) of the steady state
electron density at [latex]x=2 \mu m[/latex], is _____
solution:
From continuity equation of electrons [latex]\frac{dn}{dt}=n\mu _n\frac{dE}{dx}+\mu _nE\frac{dn}{dx}+G_n-R_n+x_n\frac{d^2x}{dx^2} \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] [Because 
 [latex]\vec{E}[/latex] is not mentioned hence [latex]\frac{dE}{dx}=0[/latex] For 
 [latex] x \gt 0, G_n[/latex]  is also zero [latex]n=\frac{n_i^2}{N_A}=\frac{10^{20}}{10^{17}}=10^3[/latex] [latex]n=n_0+\delta n=10^3+10^{14}=10^{14}[/latex] at steady state, 
[latex]\frac{db}{dt}=0[/latex] Hence equation (i) becomes: [latex]O=D_n\frac{d^2\delta n}{dx^2}-\frac{\delta n}{\tau _n}[/latex] [latex]\frac{d^2\delta n}{dx^2}=\frac{\delta n}{L_n^2} \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] From solving equation (ii) [latex]\delta _n(x)=\delta _n(0)e^{-x/L_n}[/latex] at  
[latex]x=2\mu m[/latex] [latex]\delta _n(2\mu m)=10^{14}e^{-2/2}=10^{14}e^{-1}=0.37 \times 10^{14}[/latex]

question:
Question 22 For the transistor [latex]M_{1}[/latex]
 in the circuit shown in the figure, [latex]\mu_{n} C_{\text{ox}} = 100\:\mu A/V^{2}[/latex]
 and [latex](W/L)=10[/latex], where [latex]\mu_{n}[/latex]
 is the mobility of electron, [latex]C_{\text{ox}}[/latex] is the oxide capacitance per unit area , W is the width and L is the length. The channel length modulation coefficient is ignored. If the gate-to-source voltage [latex]V_{\text{GS}}\text{ is } 1\:V[/latex]
 to keep the transistor at the edge of saturation, then the threshold voltage of the transistor (rounded off to one decimal place) is _______ V.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{D S}&=\frac{\mu_{n} C_{O x}}{2} \times \frac{W}{L}\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ \text{Given}\qquad V_{G S}&=1 \mathrm{~V} \\ I_{D S}&=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{D S}=3-20 \times I_{D S} \\ V_{D S}=3-\frac{20}{2}\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ V_{D S}=3-10\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] MOSFET operates in saturation if [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{D S} &\geq V_{G S}-V_{T}\\ \text{So, we take},\qquad \quad V_{D S}&=V_{G S}-V_{T} \\ V_{G S}-V_{T}&=3-10\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ 1-V_{T}&=3-10\left(1-V_{T}\right)^{2}\\ \text{Let,}\qquad 1-V_{T} &=x \\ 3-10 x^{2} &=x \\ 10 x^{2}+x-3 x &=0 \\ \text{We get,}\qquad x &=-\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+120}}{20}\\ x &=-\frac{1 \pm 11}{20}\\ \therefore \qquad \quad x&=0.5 \text { and }-0.6\\ x&=0.5\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \quad 1-V_{T} & =0.5 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \quad V_{T} & =0.5 \mathrm{~V} \\ x & =-0.6 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \quad 1-V_{T} & =-0.6 \\ \Rightarrow\qquad \quad V_{T} & =1.6 \mathrm{~V} \\ \text { But }\qquad \quad V_{G S} & \gt V_{T} \\ \text { or }\qquad \quad V_{T} & \lt V_{G S} \\ \text { i.e., }\qquad \quad V_{T} &  \lt 1 \\ \therefore\qquad \quad V_{T} & =0.5 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 A silicon P-N junction is shown in the figure. The doping in the P region is [latex]5\times10^{16}\:cm^{-3}[/latex]
 and doping in the N region is [latex]10\times10^{16}\:cm^{-3}[/latex]. The parameters given are Built-in voltage [latex]\left ( \Phi _{\text{bi}} \right ) = 0.8\:V[/latex] Electron charge [latex](q) = 1.6\times10^{-19} C\:[/latex] Vacuum permittivity [latex]\left ( \varepsilon _{0} \right ) = 8.85\times10^{-12}\:F/m[/latex] Relative permittivity of silicon [latex]\left ( \varepsilon _{\text{Si}} \right ) = 12[/latex] he magnitude of reverse bias voltage that would completely deplete one of the two regions (P or N) prior to the other (rounded off to one decimal place) is _________V.
solution:
Given: [latex]\quad N_{A}=5 \times 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \quad ; \quad N_{D}=10 \times 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}[/latex] Built-in potential, [latex]\quad \phi_{\mathrm{bi}}=0.8 \mathrm{~V} [/latex] Electron charge, [latex]q=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}[/latex] Vacuum permittivity, [latex]\epsilon_{o}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{m}=8.85 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{cm}[/latex] Relative permittivity silicon, [latex]
 \epsilon_{\mathrm{si}}=12[/latex] [latex]
\Rightarrow [/latex] Doping on both sides is comparable, so smaller region would deplete first. So, depletion region width on N -side [latex]=x_{n}=0.2 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned} 
\Rightarrow \qquad x_{n}&=0.2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~cm}\\
x_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \epsilon_{S i}}{q}\left(\frac{N_{A}}{N_{D}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{N_{A}+N_{D}}\right)\left(\phi_{b i}+V_{R}\right)}
\end{aligned}[/latex] where, [latex]V_{R} \rightarrow [/latex] Magnitude of reverse bias potential [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad 0.2 \times 10^{-4}&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 12 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} \cdot \frac{5 \times 10^{16}}{10 \times 10^{16}} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(15 \times 10^{16}\right)}\left(\phi_{b i}+V_{R}\right)} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad \phi_{b j}+V_{R}&=9.039\\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{R}&=9.039-0.8\\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad V_{R}&=8.239 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 For an n-channel silicon [latex]\text{MOSFET}[/latex] with [latex]10\:nm[/latex] gate oxide thickness, the substrate sensitivity [latex]\left ( \partial V_{T}/\partial \left | V_{BS} \right | \right )[/latex] is found to be [latex]50\:mV/V[/latex] at a substrate voltage [latex]\left | V_{BS} \right |=2V[/latex], where [latex]V_{T}[/latex] is the threshold voltage of the [latex]\text{MOSFET}[/latex]. Assume that, [latex]\left | V_{BS} \right | \gg 2\Phi _{B}[/latex], where [latex]q\Phi _{B}[/latex] is the separation between the Fermi energy level [latex]E_{F}[/latex] and the intrinsic level [latex]E_{i}[/latex] in the bulk. Parameters given are Electron charge [latex](q) = 1.6 \times 101^{-19}\:C[/latex] Vacuum permittivity [latex](\varepsilon _{0}) = 8.85 \times 10^{-12}\: F/m[/latex] Relative permittivity of silicon [latex](\varepsilon _{Si}) = 12[/latex] Relative permittivity of oxide [latex](\varepsilon _{ox}) = 4[/latex] The doping concentration of the substrate is
solution: Given, N -channel MOSFET [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{o x}&=10 \mathrm{~nm}=10 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~cm} & \\ \frac{\partial V_{T}}{\partial\left|V_{B S}\right|}&=50 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{V}, & \left|V_{B S}\right|=2 \mathrm{~V} \\ \qquad q&=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C} & \left|V_{B S}\right|>>2 \phi_{B} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \epsilon_{o} &=8.85 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{cm} \\ \epsilon_{r_{\mathrm{Si}}} &=12 \\ \epsilon_{r_{O x}} &=4 \end{aligned}[/latex] Threshold voltage, including body effect, [latex] V_{T}=\phi_{m s}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}\left(2 \phi_{B}-V_{B S}\right)}}{C_{o x}}+2 \phi_{B}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{In question, we need, } \left|V_{B S}\right|&=\left|V_{S B}\right| \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad V_{T}&=\phi_{m s}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}\left(2 \phi_{B}+V_{S B}\right)}}{C_{o x}}+2 \phi_{B}\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad V_{T}&=\phi_{m s}+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}\left(2 \phi_{B}+\left|V_{S B}\right|\right)}}{C_{O x}}+2 \phi_{B}\\ \therefore \qquad\qquad \frac{\partial V_{T}}{\partial\left|V_{B S}\right|}&=0+\frac{\sqrt{2 \epsilon_{s i} q N_{A}}}{C_{O x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2 \phi_{B}+\left|V_{S B}\right|}}+0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 50 \times 10^{-3}&=\frac{\sqrt{2 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14} \times 12 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{~N}_{A}}}{\epsilon_{\alpha x} / t_{0 x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\left|V_{S B}\right|}}\\ \left(\frac{50 \times 10^{-3} \times 4 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14}}{10 \times 10^{-7}}\right)^{2}&=\frac{2 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14} \times 12 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{4 \times 2}\\ &\left[\because\left|V_{S B}\right| \gt \gt 2 \phi_{B}\right]\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad N_{A}&=7.375 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 In the circuit shown in the figure, the transistors [latex]M_{1}[/latex] and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] are operating in saturation. The transconductance of the [latex]\text{MOSFETs} M_{1}[/latex] and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] are [latex]g_{m1}[/latex] and [latex]g_{m2}[/latex] , respectively, and the internal resistance of the [latex]\text{MOSFETs} M_{1}[/latex] and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] are [latex]r_{01}[/latex] and [latex]r_{02}[/latex] , respectively. Ignoring the body effect, the ac small signal voltage gain [latex]\left ( \partial V_{out}/\partial V_{in} \right )[/latex] of the circuit is
solution:
MOSFET [latex]M_2[/latex] acts as common source amplifier. Drain to gate connected MOSFET [latex]M_1[/latex] acts as load. For given circuit, AC equivalent is as shown. Replace [latex]M_2[/latex] with small signal model [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{V_{\text {out }}}{V_{\text {in }}} &=\frac{-g_{m 2} V_{g s}\left(r_{\infty} \| R_{\text {eq }}\right)}{V_{g s}} \\
A_{V} &=-g_{m 2}\left( \frac{1}{g_{m 1}}|| r_{o1} || r_{o 2} \right)
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 26 The energy band diagram of a p-type semiconductor bar of length L under equilibrium condition (i.e.. the Fermi energy level [latex]E_{F}[/latex]
 is constant) is shown in the figure. The valance band [latex]E_{V}[/latex]
 is sloped since doping is non-uniform along the bar. The difference between the energy levels of the valence band at the two edges of the bar is [latex]\Delta[/latex]. If the charge of an electron is q, then the magnitude of the electric field developed inside this semiconductor bar is
solution: The built-in electric field is due to non-uniform doping (the semiconductor is under equilibrium) [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=\frac{1}{q}\frac{ d E_{v}}{d x} \\ &=\frac{1}{q} \frac{\Delta}{L} \\ &=\frac{\Delta}{q L} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 A bar of silicon is doped with boron concentration of [latex]10^{16} \text{cm}^{-3}[/latex]  and assumed to be fully ionized. It is exposed to light such that electron-hole pairs are generated throughout the volume of the bar at the rate of [latex]10^{20} \text{cm}^{-3} s^{-1}[/latex]. If the recombination lifetime is [latex]100 \;\mu s[/latex], intrinsic carrier concentration of silicon is [latex]10^{10} \text{cm}^{-3}[/latex] and assuming [latex]100\%[/latex] ionization of boron, then the approximate product of steady-state electron and hole concentrations due to this light exposure is
solution: Boron [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Acceptor type doping [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{A} &=10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \\ g_{0 p} &=1020 \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} \\ \tau &=100 \mu \mathrm{s} \\ n_{i} &=10^{10} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Product of steady state electron-hole concentration =? At thermal equilibrium (before shining light) [latex] \begin{array}{ll} \text { Hole concentration, } & p_{o} \simeq N_{A}=10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \\ \text { Electron concentration, } & n_{0}=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{p_{0}}=\frac{10^{20}}{10^{16}}=10^{4} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{array}[/latex] After, illumination of light, Hole concentration, [latex]p=p_{o}+\delta p[/latex] Electron concentration, [latex]\quad n=n_{o}+\delta n[/latex] Due to shining light, excess carrier concentration, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta p &=\delta n=g_{o p} \cdot \tau=10^{20} \times 100 \times 10^{-6}=10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \\ \therefore \qquad p &=10^{16}+10^{16}=2 \times 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}\\ n&=10^{4}+10^{16} \simeq 10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, product of steady state electron-hole concentration [latex] \begin{aligned} &=n p=10^{16} \times 2 \times 10^{16} \\ &=2 \times 10^{32} \mathrm{~cm}^{-6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 28 A pn junction solar cell of area 1.0 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex], illuminated uniformly with 100 mW [latex]cm^{-2}[/latex],
has the following parameters: Efficiency = 15%, open circuit voltage = 0.7 V, fill
factor = 0.8, and thickness = 200 [latex]\mu m[/latex], The charge of an electron is [latex]1.6 \times 10^{-19}[/latex]C. The
average optical generation rate (in [latex]cm^{-3} s^{-1}[/latex]) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\eta &=\frac{\left ( FF \right )V_{OC}I_{SC}}{P_{in}} \\ 0.15&=\frac{0.8\times 0.7\times I_{SC}}{100mW} \\ I_{SC}&=\frac{15}{0.56}mA \\ G_{L}&=\frac{I_{SC}}{q \times \text{ Area } \times \text{ thickness } } \\ &=\frac{15 \times 10^{-3}}{0.56 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 1\times 200\times 10^{-4}} \\ &=\frac{15}{0.56\times 32}\times 10^{19}\\ &=0.837\times 10^{19} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 29 The base of an npn BJT T1 has a linear doping profile [latex]N_B(x)[/latex] as shown below. The base
of another npn BJT T2 has a uniform doping [latex]N_B[/latex] of [latex]10^{17} cm^{-3}[/latex]. All other parameters are
identical for both the devices. Assuming that the hole density profile is the same as
that of doping, the common-emitter current gain of T2 is
solution: As per GATE official answer key MTA (Marks to ALL) [latex]\frac{\beta _{1}}{\beta _{2}}=\frac{\int_{0}^{W}N_{A_{2}}(x)dx}{\int_{0}^{W}N_{A_{1}}(x)dx}=\frac{W\times 10^{17}}{\frac{1}{2}\times W\times (10^{17}-10^{14})}=\frac{2\times 10^{17}}{10^{17}+10^{14}}\simeq 2[/latex]

question:
Question 30 The band diagram of a p-type semiconductor with a band-gap of 1 eV is shown. Using
this semiconductor, a MOS capacitor having [latex]V_{TH}[/latex] of [latex]-0.16 V, C'_{ox}[/latex] of 100 [latex]nF/cm^2[/latex] and
a metal work function of 3.87 eV is fabricated. There is no charge within the oxide. If
the voltage across the capacitor is [latex]V_{TH}[/latex]. the magnitude of depletion charge per unit area
(in [latex]C/cm^2[/latex]) is

Question 31 A one-sided abrupt [latex]pn[/latex] junction diode has a depletion capacitance CD of 50 pF at a reverse
bias of 0.2 V. The plot of [latex]1/C_D^2[/latex] versus the applied voltage V for this diode is a straight
line as shown in the figure below. The slope of the plot is ____[latex]\times 10^{20} F^{-2} V^{-1}[/latex].
solution: As per GATE official answer key MTA (Marks to ALL) Depletion or transition capacitance is, [latex]C_{D}=\frac{A_{\epsilon }}{W}[/latex] For one-sided PN junction [latex]\left (EX:P^{+}N Junction \right )[/latex] [latex]W=\sqrt{\frac{2\epsilon V_{B}}{eN_{D}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2\epsilon \left ( V_{bi}-V \right )}{eN_{D}}}[/latex] where V is anode to cathode applied potential. [latex]\Rightarrow \, \, \, \, C_{D}=\frac{A\epsilon }{\sqrt{\frac{2\, \epsilon \left ( V_{bi}-V \right )}{eN_{D}}}} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \, \, \, \, \frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}=\frac{2}{A^{2}\epsilon eN_{D}}\left ( V_{bi}-V \right )[/latex] [latex] \frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}\, becomes \, zero \, at V=V_{bi}[/latex] From above graph,[latex]y=\frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}=0\, at\, x_{1}=V_{bi}[/latex] [latex] And \, \, \, y_{2}=\frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}=4\times 10^{20}\, at\, x_{2}=-0.2V [/latex] [latex]Slope=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-X_{1}}=\frac{4\times 10^{20}-0}{-0.2-V_{bi}}[/latex] [latex] V_{bi}[/latex] is not provided,slope cannot be found.

question:

diode. The maximum recombination rate is [latex]U_{max}[/latex]. If the electron and the hole capture

options.A:
With all other parameters unchanged, [latex]U_{max}[/latex] decreases if the intrinsic carrier density
is reduced.
options.B: [latex]U_{max}[/latex] occurs at the edges of the depletion region in the device.

With all other parameters unchanged,[latex]U_{max}[/latex] increases if the thermal velocity of the

of states for holes twice that of electrons. The thermal voltage is 26 mV. The intrinsic
Fermi level is shifted from mid-bandgap energy level by

question: Question 34 Consider a long-channel MOSFET with a channel length 1 [latex]\mu m[/latex] and width 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. The device parameters are acceptor concentration [latex]N_A=5 \times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex], electron mobility [latex]\mu_n=800cm^2/V-s[/latex], oxide capacitance/area [latex]C_{ox}=3.45 \times 10^{-7}F/cm^{2}[/latex], threshold voltage [latex]V_T=0.7V[/latex]. The drain saturation current ([latex]I_{Dsat}[/latex]) for a gate voltage of 5 V is _____mA(rounded off to two decimal places). [latex][\varepsilon _0=8.854 \times 10^{-14}F/cm,\varepsilon _{Si}=11.9][/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{D(\text { sat })} &=\frac{1}{2} \mu_{n} C_{\text {ox }} \frac{W}{L}\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times 800 \times 3.45 \times 10^{-7} \times \frac{10}{1}(5-0.7)^{2} \mathrm{A} \\ &=25.5162 \mathrm{mA} \simeq 25.52 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 In an ideal pn junction with an ideality factor of 1 at T=300 K, the magnitude of the reverse-bias voltage required to reach 75% of its reverse saturation current, rounded off to 2 decimal places, is ____mV. [[latex]k=1.38 \times 10^{-23}JK^{-1}[/latex], [latex]h=6.625 \times 10^{-34}J-s[/latex], [latex]q=1.602 \times 10^{-19}C[/latex]]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{T} &=\frac{k T}{q}=\frac{1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 300}{1.602 \times 10^{-19}} \mathrm{V} \\ &=25.843 \mathrm{mV} \\ I &=I_{0}\left(e^{V / V_{T}}-1\right)=-\frac{3}{4} I_{0} \\ \Rightarrow\quad V &=V_{T} \ln 0.25=-35.83 \mathrm{mV} \\ V_{R} &=|V|=35.83 \mathrm{mV} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 A Germanium sample of dimensions 1cmx1cm is illuminated with a 20 mW, 600 nm laser light source as shown in the figure. The illuminated sample surface has a 100 nm of loss-less Silicon dioxide layer that reflects one-fourth of the incident light. From the remaining light, one-third of the power is reflected from the Silicon dioxide-Germanium interface, one-third is absorbed in the Germanium layer, and one-third is transmitted through the other side of the sample. If the absorption coefficient of Germanium at 600 nm is [latex]3 \times 10^4 cm^{-1}[/latex] and the bandgap is 0.66 eV, the thickness of the Germanium layer, rounded off to 3 decimal places, is ______ [latex]\mu m[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{\text {absorbed }} &=P_{\text {incident }}\left(1-e^{-\alpha T}\right) \\ \frac{1}{3} &=\frac{2}{3}\left(1-e^{-\alpha T}\right) \\ \frac{2}{3} e^{-\alpha T} &=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] where [latex]\alpha=3 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{cm}^{-1}[/latex], absorption coefficient of Ge sample. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad T &=\frac{1}{\alpha} \ln (2)=\frac{1}{3 \times 10^{4}} \ln (2) \mathrm{cm} \\ &=0.231 \mu \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The quantum efficiency ([latex]\eta[/latex]) and responsivity (R) at a wavelength [latex]\lambda (in \; \mu m)[/latex] in a p-i-n photodetector are related by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta&=\frac{I_{\text {out }}}{q} \times \frac{h f}{P_{\text {in }}} \\ R&=\frac{I_{\text {out }}}{P_{\text {in }}}\\ \text{So, }\quad R&=\eta \times \frac{q}{h f}=\eta \times \frac{q \lambda}{h c} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] If [latex]\lambda[/latex] is given in [latex]\mu \mathrm{m},[/latex] then [latex] \begin{aligned} R &=\eta \lambda \times \frac{q \times 10^{-6}}{h c} \\ \frac{h c}{q \times 10^{-6}} & \simeq 1.24\\ \text{So, }\quad R&=\frac{\eta \lambda}{1.24} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Since [latex]\phi_{ms}= 0[/latex], the MOS-capacitor is ideal. Point P Represents accumulation Point Q Represents flat band Point R Represents Inversion

Question 41 A junction is made between [latex] p^{-} Si [/latex] with doping density [latex] N_{A1} = 10^{15} cm^{-3}[/latex] and pSi with doping density[latex] N_{A2} = 10^{17} cm^{-3} [/latex]. Given: Boltzmann constant [latex]k = 1.38 \times  10^{-23} JK^{-1} [/latex], electronic charge [latex] q = 1.6 \times  10^{-19} C [/latex]. Assume 100% acceptor ionization. At room temperature (T = 300K), the magnitude of the built-in potential (in volts, correct to
two decimal places) across this junction will be _________________.
solution: Built-in potential, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{b i} &=\frac{k T}{q} \ln \left(\frac{N_{A 2}}{N_{A 1}}\right) \\ &=\frac{1.38 \times 3}{1.6 \times 100} \ln (100) \mathrm{V}=0.1192 \mathrm{V} \\ & \simeq 0.12 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 42 A solar cell of area  1.0 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex] , operating at 1.0 sun intensity, has a short circuit current of
20 mA, and an open circuit voltage of 0.65 V. Assuming room temperature operation and
thermal equivalent voltage of 26mV, the open circuit voltage (in volts, correct to two
decimal places) at 0.2 sun intensity is _______.
solution: For solar cell, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{OC}} &=V_{T} \ln \left(\frac{I_{S C}}{I_{O}}\right) \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2}-V_{\mathrm{OC} 1} &=V_{T} \ln \left(\frac{I_{S C 2}}{I_{S C}}\right)=V_{T} \ln \left(\frac{0.20}{1.0}\right) \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2} &=V_{\mathrm{OC} 1}-0.026 \mathrm{ln}(5) \\ &=0.65-0.041845=0.608 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 Red (R), Green (G) and Blue (B) Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) were fabricated using p-n
junctions of three different inorganic semiconductors having different band-gaps. The builtin
voltages of red, green and blue diodes are [latex] V_{R}, V_{G} \; and \; V_{B} [/latex], respectively. Assume donor and acceptor doping to be the same [latex] (N_{A} \; and \; N_{D} [/latex], respectively) in the p and n sides of all the three diodes. Which one of the following relationships about the built-in voltages is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\lambda_{R} \gt \lambda_{G} \gt \lambda_{B}[/latex] Energy gap, [latex] E_{g} \propto \frac{1}{\lambda} [/latex] So, [latex]E_{g R} \lt E_{g G}  \lt  E_{g B}[/latex] Materials with high energy gap will have high built-in voltages, when doping concentrations are same. So, [latex]V_{R} \lt V_{G}  \lt V_{B}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 There are two photolithography systems: one with light source of wavelength [latex]\lambda _{1}[/latex] = 156 nm
(System 1) and another with light source of wavelength [latex]\lambda _{2}[/latex] = 325 nm (System 2). Both
photolithography systems are otherwise identical. If the minimum feature sizes that can be
realized using System1 and System2 are [latex] L_{min1} \; and \; L_{min2} [/latex] respectively, the ratio [latex] L_{min1}/L_{min2} [/latex](correct to two decimal places) is__________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{min}&\propto \lambda \\ \frac{L_{min1}}{L_{min2}}&=\frac{\lambda _1}{\lambda _2} \\ &= \frac{156nm}{325nm}=0.48 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 A p-n step junction diode with a contact potential of 0.65V has a depletion width of 1[latex]\mu[/latex]m
at equilibrium. The forward voltage (in volts, correct to two decimal places) at which this
width reduces to 0.6 [latex]\mu[/latex]m is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{\mathrm{dep}} &=\sqrt{\frac{2 \varepsilon}{q}\left(\frac{1}{N_{A}}+\frac{1}{N_{D}}\right)\left(V_{b i}-V_{A K}\right)} \\ \frac{\sqrt{\left(0.65-V_{A K}\right)}}{\sqrt{0.65}} &=\frac{0.6 \mu \mathrm{m}}{1 \mu \mathrm{m}}=0.6 \\ 1-\frac{V_{A K}}{0.65} &=0.36 \\ V_{A K} &=0.65(1-0.36) \\ &=0.65 \times 0.64=0.416 \mathrm{V} \simeq 0.42 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 Two n-channel MOSFETs, T1 and T2, are identical in all respects except that the width of T2 is double that of T1. Both the transistors are biased in the saturation region of operation, but the gate overdrive voltage ([latex]V_{GS}-V_{TH}[/latex]) of T2 is double that of T1, where [latex]V_{GS} \; and \; V_{TH}[/latex] are the gate-to-source voltage and threshold voltage of the transistors, respectively. If the drain current and transconductance of T1 are [latex]I_{D1} \; and \; g_{m1}[/latex] respectively, the corresponding values of these two parameters for T2 are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{2} &=2 \mathrm{W} \\ V_{\text {GS2 }}-V_{T 2} &=\left(V_{G S 1}-V_{T 1}\right) \\ \frac{I_{D 2}}{I_{D 1}} &=\frac{W_{2}}{W_{1}} \times\left(\frac{V_{G S 2}-V_{T 2}}{V_{G S 1}-V_{T 1}}\right)^{2} \\ &=2 \times 4=8 \\ I_{D 2} &=8 I_{D 1} \\ \frac{g_{m 2}}{g_{m 1}} &=\frac{W_{2}}{W_{1}} \times \frac{V_{G S 2}-V_{T 2}}{V_{G S 1}-V_{T 1}}=2 \times 2=4 \\ g_{m 2} &=4 g_{m 1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 For a particular intensity of incident light on a silicon pn junction solar cell, the photocurrent density ([latex]J_{L}[/latex]) is 2.5 mA/[latex]cm^{2}[/latex] and the open-circuit voltage ([latex]V_{oc}[/latex]) is 0.451 V. consider thermal voltage ([latex]V_{T}[/latex]) to be 25mV. If the intensity of the incident light is increased by 20 times,assuming that the temperature remains unchanged. [latex]V_{oc} [/latex](in volts) will be ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{OC}} &=V_{T} \ln \frac{J_{L}}{J_{S}} \quad J_{L} \propto \text { Light intensity } \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2}-V_{\mathrm{OC} 1} &=V_{T} \ln \frac{J_{L 2}}{J_{L 1}} \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2}-V_{\mathrm{OC} 1} &=25 \ln 20 \cong 75 \mathrm{mV}=0.075 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{\mathrm{OC} 2} &=0.451 \mathrm{V}+0.075 \mathrm{V}=0.526 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Oxide [latex]\in_{r}=3.9,\in_{o}=8.85 \times 10^{-14}[/latex] F/cm, oxide thickness [latex]t_{ox} = 0.1 \mu m[/latex] and electronic charge [latex] q =1.6 \times 10^{-19} C[/latex]. If the measured flat band voltage of the capacitor is -1V, then the magnitude of the fixed charge at the oxide-semiconductor
interface, in [latex]nC/cm^{2}[/latex], is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta_{0} &=4.1 \mathrm{eV} \\ e_{K} &=4 \mathrm{eV} \\ E_{C}-E_{F P} &=0.9 \mathrm{eV} \\ e \phi_{s} &=e x+0.9=4.9 \mathrm{eV} \\ \phi_{m} &=4.1 \mathrm{V}, \quad \phi_{s}=4.9 \mathrm{V} \\ \phi_{m s} &=\phi_{m}-\phi_{s}=4.1-4.9=-0.8 \mathrm{v} \\ C_{o x} &=\frac{\epsilon_{O x}}{t_{o x}}=\frac{3.9 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-14}}{0.1 \times 10^{-4}}\\ &=34.515 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{F} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\ V_{F B} &=\phi_{\text {rns }}-\frac{\phi_{o x}^{\prime}}{C_{O x}} \\ \frac{\phi_{O x}^{\prime}}{C_{O x}} &=-0.8+1=0.2 \mathrm{V} \\ \phi_{o x}^{\prime} &=0.2 \times C_{0 x} \\ &=0.2 \times 34.515 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\ &=6.903 \mathrm{nC} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 An npn bipolar junction transistor (BJT) is operating in the active region. If the reverse bias across the base - collector junction is increased, then
solution:
When a BJT is in active region, as the reverse 
bias voltage across collector-base junction 
increased, the width of depletion region increases, 
which results in decrease of effective base width. 
This decrease in effective base width reduces the 
recombinations in base region, hence, common-emitter 
current gain will increase.

options.A: the effective base width increases and common - emitter current gain increases
options.B: the effective base width increases and common - emitter current gain decreases
options.C: the effective base width decreases and common - emitter current gain increases
options.D: the effective base width decreases and common -  emitter current gain decreases

question: Question 52 Consider an n-channel MOSFET having width W, length L, electron mobility in the channel [latex]\mu_{n}[/latex] and oxide capacitance per unit area [latex]C_{ox}[/latex]. If gate-to-source voltage [latex]V_{GS}[/latex]=0.7V, drain-tosource voltage [latex]V_{DS}=0.1V,(\mu_{n}C_{ox})=100\mu A/V^{2}[/latex],threshold voltage [latex]V_{TH}=0.3 V [/latex] and (W/L)=50,then the transconductance [latex]g_{m}[/latex](in mA/V) is ___________.
solution: Given that, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{G S} &=0.7 \mathrm{V}, V_{T H}=0.3 \mathrm{V}, V_{D S}=0.1 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{G S}-V_{T H} &=0.4>V_{D S} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] MOSFET is in linear region In linear region, [latex] I_{D}=K_{n}\left[2\left(V_{G S}-V_{T H}\right) V_{O S}-V_{D S}^{2}\right][/latex] Transconductance [latex] \begin{aligned} g_{m}&=\frac{\partial I_{D}}{\partial V_{G S}}=2 K_{n} V_{D S} \\ K_{n}&=\frac{K_{n}}{2}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)=\frac{\mu_{n} C_{O x}}{2}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)\\ \text{So,}\quad g_{m} &=2 K_{n} V_{D S}=\mu_{n} C_{O x}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right) V_{D S} \\ &=100 \times 50 \times 0.1 \mu \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{V} \\ &=0.5 \mathrm{mA} N \end{aligned}[/latex]

Net hole density varying in the direction of x is, [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{n}(x) &=p_{n 0}+\Delta p=p_{n 0}+G_{L} \tau_{p} \\ &=p_{n 0}+G_{L o} \tau_{p}\left(1-\frac{x}{L}\right) \\ J_{p, \text { diff }} &=-e D_{p} \frac{d p}{d x}=-e D_{p}\left[\frac{-G_{L o} \tau_{p}}{L}\right] \\ &=\frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 100 \times 10^{17} \times 10^{-4}}{0.1 \times 10^{-4}} \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\ &=16 \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 The dependence of drift velocity of electrons on electric field in a semiconductor is shown below. The semiconductor has a uniform electron concentration of [latex]n=1\times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] and electronic charge [latex]q=1.6\times 10^{-19}C[/latex]. If a bias of 5V is applied across a 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]m region of this semiconductor, the resulting current density in this region, in [latex]kA/cm^{2}[/latex], is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E&=\frac{V}{d}=\frac{5}{10^{-4}}=5 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{cm}\\ &\text{Slope of the curve,}\\ m &=\frac{10^{7}-0}{5 \times 10^{5}}=20 \quad y=m_{x} \\ v_{d} &=20 \times E=20 \times 5 \times 10^{4} \\ &=10^{6} \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{cm} \\ J &=n e v_{d} \\ &=1 \times 10^{16} \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 10^{6} \\ &=1.6 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}=1.6 \mathrm{kA} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 As shown, two Silicon (Si) abrupt p-n junction diodes are fabricated with uniform donor doping concentration of [latex]N_{D1}=10^{14}cm^{-3}[/latex] and [latex]N_{D2}=10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] in the n-regions of the diodes,
and uniform acceptor doping concentration of [latex]N_{A1}=10^{14}cm^{-3} [/latex] and [latex]N_{A2}=10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex]  in the pregions of the diodes, respectively. Assuming that the reverse bias voltage is [latex]\gt \gt[/latex] built-in potentials of the diodes, the ratio [latex]\frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}}[/latex]  of their reverse bias capacitances for the same applied reverse bias, is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \varepsilon V_{R}}{e}\left(\frac{1}{N_{A}}+\frac{1}{N_{D}}\right)} \\ \because \; &V_{R}\gt \gt V_{bi}\\ \text{Under reverse } &\text{biased condition,}\\ C&=\frac{\varepsilon A}{W} \quad \Rightarrow C \propto \frac{1}{W}\\ \text{So}\quad\frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}} &=\frac{W_{1}}{W_{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{\frac{2 \varepsilon V_{R}}{e}\left(\frac{2}{10^{14}}\right)}{\frac{2 \varepsilon V_{R}}{e}\left(\frac{2}{10^{16}}\right)}}=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 56 An [latex]n^{+} -n[/latex] Silicon device is fabricated with uniform and non-degenerate donor doping concentrations of [latex]N_{D1}=1 \times 10^{18}cm^{-3}[/latex]  and [latex]N_{D2}=1 \times 10^{15}cm^{-3}[/latex] corresponding to the [latex]n^{+}[/latex] and n
regions respectively. At the operational temperature T, assume complete impurity ionization, kT/q = 25 mV, and intrinsic carrier concentration to be [latex]n_{i}=1 \times 10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex] . What is the magnitude of the built-in potential of this device?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{0} &=V_{T} \ln \frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=V_{T} \ln \frac{N_{D 1}}{N_{D 2}} \\ &=0.25 \ln \frac{10^{18}}{10^{15}}=0.025 \ln (1000) \\ &=0.173 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 For a narrow base PNP BJT, the excess minority carrier concentration ([latex]\Delta n_{E}[/latex] for emitter, [latex]\Delta p_{E0}[/latex] for base. Which one of the following biasing modes is the transistor operating in ?
solution: Emitter-base junction [latex](J_{E})[/latex] is in RB Collector-base junction [latex](J_{C})[/latex] is in FB Hence, inverse active mode.

question: Question 58 A bar of Gallium Arsenide (GaAs) is doped with Silicon such that the Silicon atoms occupy Gallium and Arsenic sites in the GaAs crystal. Which one of the following statement is true?
solution: Si acts as p-type dopant GA sites. Si acts as n-type dopant GA sites.

options.B: Silicon atoms act as n-type dopants in Arsenic sites and p-type dopants in Gallium sites

question: Question 59 Figures I and II show two MOS capacitors of unit area. The capacitor in Figure I has insulator materials X (of thickness [latex]t_1 = 1[/latex]nm and dielectric constant [latex]\varepsilon _{1}[/latex] = 4) and Y (of thickness [latex]t_2 = 3 [/latex]nm and dielectric constant [latex]\varepsilon _{2}[/latex] = 20). The capacitor in Figure II has only insulator material X of thickness [latex]t_{Eq}[/latex]. If the capacitors are of equal capacitance, then the value of [latex]t_{Eq}[/latex] (in nm) is __________
solution: From the figure I. Both the capacitors [latex]C_{1}[/latex] and [latex]C_{2}[/latex] are in series Total Capacitance, [latex]C=\frac{C_{1} C_{2}}{C_{1}+C_{2}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} C=& \frac{A e_{1}}{A_{1}} \cdot \frac{A \varepsilon_{2}}{t_{2}} \\ =& \frac{A x_{1}+A \varepsilon_{2}}{t_{1}}+\frac{A \times 20}{12} \\ =& \frac{10^{-9} \cdot \frac{A \times 10^{-9}}{4 \times 4}+\frac{A \times 20}{3 \times 10^{-9}}}{10^{-9}} \\ C=& 2.5 \times 10^{9} \times A \end{aligned}[/latex] From figure II [latex] C=\frac{\varepsilon A}{t_{\theta q}}[/latex] since both capacitors must be equal in figures I  and II [latex] \begin{array}{r} 2.5 \times 10^{9} \times A=\frac{A \times 4}{t_{e q}} \\ t_{e q}=1.6 \mathrm{nm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 60 The injected excess electron concentration profile in the base region of an npn BJT, biased in the active region, is linear, as shown in the figure. If the area of the emitter-base junction is 0.001 [latex]cm^{2},\mu _{n}=800 cm^{2}/(V-s)[/latex] in the base region and depletion layer widths are negligible, then the collector current [latex]I_{C}[/latex] (in mA) at room temperature is __________ (Given: thermal voltage [latex]V_{T}[/latex] = 26 mV at room temperature, electronic charge [latex]q=1.6\times 10^{-19}C[/latex])
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{c} &=A q D_{n} \frac{d n}{d x} \text { where } D_{n}=\mu_{n} V_{T} \\ &=0.001\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right) 800 \times 26 \times 10^{-3}\left[\frac{10^{14}}{0.5 \times 10^{-4}}\right] \\ &=66.56 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{A}=6.656 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 61 The figure shows the I-V characteristics of a solar cell illuminated uniformly with solar light of power [latex]100 mW/cm^{2}[/latex]. The solar cell has an area of [latex]3cm^{2}[/latex] and a fill factor of 0.7. The maximum efficiency (in %) of the device is __________
solution: Fill factor [latex]=\frac{\text { Maximum obtained power }}{V_{O C} \cdot I_{S C}} [/latex] [latex] 0.7=\frac{\text { Maximum obtained power }}{0.5 \times 180 \times 10^{-3}} [/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Maximum obtained power, [latex]P_{m}=0.063 \mathrm{W} [/latex] Efficiency [latex]\eta=\frac{P_{m}}{G \cdot A}=\frac{0.063}{100 \times 10^{-3} \times 3}=21 \% [/latex] G [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] input light in [latex]\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}[/latex]

E_{G}=1.3 \mathrm{V} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 64 Consider a long-channel NMOS transistor with source and body connected together. Assume that the electron mobility is independent of [latex]V_{GS}[/latex] and [latex]V_{DS}[/latex]. Given, [latex]g_{m}=0.5 \mu A/V \; for \;  V_{DS}=50mV \; and \; V_{GS}=2 V[/latex], [latex]g_{d}=8 \mu A/V \; for \;  V_{GS}=2V \; and \; V_{DS}=0 V[/latex], where [latex]g_{m}=\frac{\partial I_{D}}{\partial V_{GS}}[/latex] and   [latex]g_{d}=\frac{\partial I_{D}}{\partial V_{DS}}[/latex] The threshold voltage (in volts) of the transistor is ________
solution: since [latex]V_{G S} \gt V_{D S}[/latex] MOSFET is in linear operation [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{D} &=K_{N}^{\prime}\left[V_{G S}-V_{T}\right] V_{D S} \\ \frac{d I_{D}}{d V_{G S}} &=K_{N} V_{D S} \\ g_{m} &=K_{N}^{\prime} V_{D S} \\ 0.5 \times 10^{-6} &=K_{N}^{\prime}\left[50 \times 10^{-3}\right] \therefore K_{N}^{\prime}=10^{-5} \\ I_{D} &=K_{N}\left[V_{G S}-V_{T}\right] V_{D S} \\ \frac{d I_{D}}{d V_{D S}} &=K_{N}\left[V_{G S}-V_{T}\right] \\ g_{d} &=K_{N}\left[V_{G S}-V_{T}\right] \\ 8 \times 10^{-6} &=10^{-5}\left[2-V_{T}\right] \\ \text { On solving } V_{T} &=1.2 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 Consider a region of silicon devoid of electrons and holes, with an ionized donor density of [latex]N_{d}^{+}=10^{17}cm^{-3}[/latex]. The electric field at x= 0 is 0 V/cm and the electric field at x=L is 50 kV/cm in the positive x direction. Assume that the electric field is zero in the y and z directions at all points. Given [latex]q=1.6\times 10^{-19}[/latex]coulomb,  [latex]\epsilon _{0}=8.85\times 10^{-14}F/cm,\epsilon _{r}=11.7[/latex] for silicon, the value of L in nm is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} |\varepsilon|&=\frac{q}{\varepsilon} N_{D} X_{N} \\ 50 \times 10^{3}&=\frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{8.85 \times 10^{-14} \times 11.7} \times 10^{17} \times X_{N} \\ \text { On solving, } \quad X_{N} &=3.2356 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{cm} \\ &=3.236 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{m} \\ x_{N} &=L=32.36 \mathrm{nm}\\ &=L=32.36 \mathrm{nm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 66 Consider avalanche breakdown in a silicon [latex]p^{+}n[/latex] junction. The n-region is uniformly doped with a donor density [latex]N_{D}[/latex]. Assume that breakdown occurs when the magnitude of the electric field at any
point in the device becomes equal to the critical field [latex]E_{crit}[/latex]. Assume [latex]E_{crit}[/latex] to be independent of [latex]N_{D}[/latex]. If the built-in voltage of the [latex]p^{+}n[/latex] junction is much smaller than the breakdown voltage,[latex]V_{BR}[/latex], the relationship between [latex]V_{BR}[/latex] and [latex]N_{D}[/latex] is given by
solution: In any type of PN junction [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{B R} &\propto \frac{1}{\text { Doping Concentration }}\\ \text{i.e.}\quad V_{B R} &\propto \frac{1}{N_{D}} \text { (or)  } V_{B R}=\frac{\varepsilon E^{2}}{2 q N_{D}} \\ \therefore V_{BR} \times N_{D} \rightarrow &\text { is a constant } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 A voltage [latex]V_{G}[/latex]  is applied across a MOS capacitor with metal gate and p-type silicon substrate at T=300 K. The inversion carrier density (in number of carriers per unit area) for [latex]V_{G}=0.8 V[/latex] is [latex]2\times 10^{11} cm^{-2}[/latex]. For [latex]V_{G}=1.3 V[/latex], the inversion carrier density is [latex]4\times 10^{11}cm^{-2}[/latex]. What is the value of the inversion carrier density for [latex]V_{G}=1.8 V[/latex]?
solution: In a MOS - Capacitor [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(V_{G 1}-V_{T}\right) & \propto Q \\ \frac{\left(V_{G 1}-V_{T}\right)}{\left(V_{G 2}-V_{T}\right)} &=\frac{Q_{1}}{Q_{2}} \\ \frac{0.8-V_{T}}{1.3-V_{T}} &=\frac{2 \times 10^{11}}{4 \times 10^{11}} \\ \text { On solving, } \quad V_{T} &=0.3 \mathrm{V}\\ \text{Now Consider, } &\frac{V_{G 2}-V_{T}}{V_{G 3}-V_{T}}=\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{3}} \\ \frac{1.3-0.3}{1.8-0.3}&=\frac{4 \times 10^{11}}{Q_{3}}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Inverse charge density with [latex]V_{G}=1.8 \mathrm{V} [/latex] [latex] Q_{3}=6 \times 10^{11} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 68 A long-channel NMOS transistor is biased in the linear region with [latex]V_{DS}[/latex]=50 mV and is used as a resistance. Which one of the following statements is NOT correct?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} r_{ds} &=\frac{1}{\mu_{n} C_{01} \frac{W}{L}\left(V_{\mathrm{as}}-v_{r}\right)} \\ r_{ds} &=\text { channel resistance } \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} W \uparrow r \downarrow A \rightarrow \text { correct } \\ V_{T} \downarrow r \downarrow B \rightarrow \text { correct } \\ L \uparrow r \uparrow C \rightarrow \text { correct } \\ V_{\triangle} \uparrow r \downarrow \therefore D \rightarrow \text { Wrong statement } \end{array}[/latex]

options.A: If the device width W is increased, the resistance decreases.
options.B: If the threshold voltage is reduced, the resistance decreases.
options.C: If the device length L is increased, the resistance increases.
options.D: If [latex]V_{GS}[/latex] is increased, the resistance increases.

question:
Question 69 Consider a silicon sample at T = 300 K, with a uniform donor density [latex]N_{d}=5 \times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] illuminated uniformly such that the optical generation rate is [latex]G_{opt}=1.5 \times 10^{20}cm^{-3}s^{-1}[/latex]
throughout the sample. The incident radiation is turned off at t = 0. Assume low-level injection to be valid and ignore surface effects. The carrier lifetimes are [latex]\tau _{p0}=0.1 \mu s \; and \;  \tau _{n0}=0.5\mu s[/latex] The hole concentration at t = 0 and the hole concentration at t= 0.3 [latex]\mu[/latex]s, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given}quad G_{opt} &=1.5 \times 10^{20} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \\ G_{opt} &=R=\frac{N_{A}}{\tau_{P}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.5 \times 10^{2} &=\frac{N_{A}}{0.1 \times 10^{-6}} \\ \therefore\quad N_{A} &=1.5 \times 10^{13} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ P(t) &=P_{n0} e^{-t / \tau_{p}} \\ &=1.5 \times 10^{13} e^{\frac{-0.3}{0.1}} \\ &=7.46 \times 10^{11} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 The figure below shows the doping distribution in a p-type semiconductor in log scale.  The magnitude of the electric field (in kV/cm) in the semiconductor due to non uniform doping is _________
solution: Applying the current density equation [latex] \begin{aligned} J&=J_{\text {Dritt }}+J_{\text {Diff }} \\ J&=0\\ 0 &=-q D_{p} \frac{d p}{d x}+q\mu_{p} p E \\ q D_{p} \frac{d p}{d x} &=a \mu_{p} p E \\ E &=\frac{V_{T}}{p(x)} \frac{\partial p}{d r} \\ \therefore \quad |E| &=\frac{V_{T}}{\rho(x)} \frac{\partial p}{d x} \\ E &=v_{7} \frac{d}{d x} \ln \left[N_{A}(x)\right] \\ E &=V_{T}\left[\frac{\ln \left(10^{16}\right)-\ln \left(10^{14}\right)}{(2-1) \times 10^{-4}}\right] \\ &=0.026\left[\frac{36-32.23}{1 \times 10^{-4}}\right] \\ &=1198.6 \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{cm} \\ &=1.198 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 Consider an n-channel metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistor (MOSFET) with a gate-tosource voltage of 1.8V. Assume that [latex]\frac{W}{L}=4[/latex], [latex]\mu _{N}C_{ox}=70\times 10^{-6}AV^{-2}[/latex], the threshold voltage is 0.3V, and the channel length modulation parameter is 0.09 [latex]V^{-1}[/latex]. In the saturation region, the drain conductance (in micro seimens) is ________
solution: In the saturation region, [latex] \begin{aligned} g_{d} &=\lambda I_{O S} \\ &=\lambda\left[\frac{1}{2} \mu_{n} C_{o x} \frac{w}{L}\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2}\right] \\ &=0.09\left[\frac{1}{2} \times 70 \times 10^{-6} \times 4(1.8-0.3)^{2}\right] \\ g_{d} &=28.35 \mu \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 72 Consider a silicon p-n junction with a uniform acceptor doping concentration of [latex]10^{17}cm^{-3}[/latex] on the pside and a uniform donor doping concentration of [latex]10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] on the n-side. No external voltage is
applied to the diode. Given: kT/q=26mV,  [latex]n_{i}=1.5\times 10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex], [latex]\varepsilon _{Si}=12\varepsilon _{0},\varepsilon _{0}=8.85\times 10^{-14}F/m,[/latex] and [latex]q=1.6\times 10^{-19}C[/latex]. The charge per unit junction area (nC [latex]cm^{-2}[/latex]) in the depletion region on the p-side is ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{0}&=V_{T} \ln \frac{N_{A} N_{D}}{n_{i}^{2}} \\ &=26 \times 10^{-3} \ln \frac{10^{16} \times 10^{17}}{\left(1.5 \times 10^{10}\right)^{2}} \\ V_{0}&=0.757 \mathrm{V} \\ W&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \varepsilon}{q}\left(\frac{1}{N_{A}}+\frac{1}{N_{D}}\right) V_{0}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 8.854 \times 10^{-16} \times 12}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}}\left[\frac{1}{10^{16}}+\frac{1}{10^{17}}\right] 0.757} \\ W&=3.3255 \mu \mathrm{cm} \\ W_{P}&=\frac{W N_{D}}{N_{A}+N_{D}}=\frac{3.3255 \times 10^{-6} \times 10^{16}}{10^{16}+10^{17}} \\ &=0.3023 \mu \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Charge per unit junction area in the depletion layer on p side is [latex] \begin{aligned} &=-q N_{A} W_{P} \\ &=-1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 10^{17} \times 0.3023 \times 10^{-6} \\ &=-4.8368 \mathrm{nC} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 Consider the following statements for a metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistor (MOSFET): P: As channel length reduces, OFF-state current increases. Q: As channel length reduces, output resistance increases. R: As channel length reduces, threshold voltage remains constant. S: As channel length reduces, ON current increases. Which of the above statements are INCORRECT?

question: Question 75 An npn BJT having reverse saturation current [latex]I_{S} = 10^{-15}[/latex] A is biased in the forward active region with [latex]V_{BE}[/latex] = 700 mV. The thermal voltage ( [latex]V_{T}[/latex] ) is 25 mV and the current gain ([latex]\beta[/latex]) may vary from 50 to 150 due to manufacturing variations. The maximum emitter current (in [latex]\mu[/latex]A) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{C} &=I_{s} e^{V_{B E} / V_{T}} \\ I_{E} &=\frac{\beta+1}{\beta} I_{C} \\ &=\frac{\beta+1}{\beta} I_{S} \cdot e^{V_{B E} / V_{T}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] I_{E}[/latex] will be maximum when [latex]\beta[/latex] is 50. [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(1.02)\left(10^{-9} \times 10^{-6}\right) e^{\frac{700 \times 10^{-3}}{25 \times 10^{-3}}} \\ &=1475 \mu \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 The current in an enhancement mode NMOS transistor biased in saturation mode was measured to be 1 mA at a drain-source voltage of 5 V. When the drain-source voltage was increased to 6 V while keeping gate-source voltage same, the drain current increased to 1.02 mA. Assume that drain to source saturation voltage is much smaller than the applied drain-source voltage. The channel length modulation parameter  [latex]\lambda[/latex] (in [latex]V^{-1}[/latex]) is _______.
solution: [latex]\lambda=\frac{\Delta I_{D}}{I_{D} \Delta V_{D S}}=\frac{0.02 \mathrm{mA}}{1 \mathrm{mA} \times 1 \mathrm{V}}=0.02[/latex]

question: Question 77 The electric field profile in the depletion region of a p-n junction in equilibrium is shown in the figure. Which one of the following statements is NOT TRUE?

question: Question 80 The energy band diagram and the electron density profile n(x) in a semiconductor are shown in the figures. solution:
The concentration of doping is not uniform 
throughout the semiconductor, thus to maintain

question: Question 81 In a MOS capacitor with an oxide layer thickness of 10 nm, the maximum depletion layer thickness is 100 nm. The permittivities of the semiconductor and the oxide layer are [latex]\varepsilon_{s} \; and  \;\varepsilon_{ox}[/latex] respectively.Assuming [latex]\varepsilon_{s} / \varepsilon_{ox} = 3[/latex], the ratio of the maximum capacitance to the minimum capacitance of this MOS capacitor is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{C_{\max }}{C_{\min }}=& \frac{\frac{\epsilon_{O x}}{t_{O x}}}{\frac{E_{O x}}{t_{O x}} \times \frac{\epsilon_{S}}{X_{d m a x}}}=\left[1+\frac{X_{d \max }}{t_{o x}} \times \frac{\epsilon_{0 x}}{\epsilon_{s}}\right] \\ & \frac{\epsilon_{O x}}{t_{O x}}+\frac{\epsilon_{S}}{X_{d m a x}} \\ &=\left[1+\frac{100}{10} \times \frac{1}{3}\right]=4.33 \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: As per the graph, mobility of electrons at the concentration [latex]10^{16}/cm^{3} \text{ is } 1200 cm^{2}/V-s. question: Question 84 An n-type silicon sample is uniformly illuminated with light which generates [latex]10^{20}[/latex] electron-hole pairs per [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] per second. question: Question 85 For the NMOSFET in the circuit shown, the threshold voltage is [latex]V_{th}[/latex] , where [latex]V_{th}[/latex] > 0. Neglecting the channel length modulation, the drain current [latex]I_{D}[/latex] as a function of [latex]V_{SS}[/latex] is represented by
solution: [latex]V_{G S}=V_{D S}[/latex] Hence MOS transistor is in saturation. In saturation, [latex] I_{D}=k\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2}=k\left(V_{D D}-V_{S S}-V_{T}\right)^{2}[/latex] As, [latex]V_{S S}[/latex] increases [latex]I_{D}[/latex] decreases (Not linearly because square factor) Hence option (a) is correct.

question:
Question 86 For a silicon diode with long P and N regions, the accepter and donor impurity concentrations are [latex]1 \times 10^{17} cm^{-3}[/latex] and [latex] 1 \times 10^{15} cm^{-3}[/latex], respectively. The lifetimes of electrons in P region and holes in N region are both 100 [latex]\mu s[/latex]. The electron and hole diffusion coefficients are [latex]49 cm^{2}/s \; and \; 36 cm^{2}/s[/latex],
respectively. Assume kT/q = 26 mV, the intrinsic carrier concentration is [latex]1 \times 10^{10} cm^{-3}, \; and \;  q = 1.6 \times  10^{-19}[/latex] C. When a forward voltage of 208 mV is applied across the diode, the hole current density (in nA/[latex]cm^{2}[/latex]) injected from P region to N region is _____________.
solution: The hole current density injected from P region to N region is given by [latex] \frac{q n_{i}^{2} D_{p}}{N_{D} L_{p}}\left[\exp \left(\frac{V_{F B}}{\eta V_{T}}\right)-1\right][/latex] where, q= charge on electron [latex] n_{i}=[/latex] Intrinsic carrier concentration in silicon [latex] N_{D}=[/latex] Donor doping [latex] D_{p}=[/latex] Hole diffusion coefficient [latex] L_{p}=[/latex] Mean diffusion length of hole [latex] V_{F B}=[/latex] Forward voltage applied across diode [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{T}=& k T / q=26 \mathrm{mV} \\ L_{p} &=\sqrt{\tau_{p} D_{p}}=\sqrt{100 \times 10^{-6} \times 36} \\ &=0.06 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using the above values, we get hole current  density injected from P region to N region

question: Question 87 A MOSFET in saturation has a drain current of 1 mA for [latex]V_{DS} = 0.5 [/latex] V. If the channel length modulation coefficient is 0.05 [latex]V^{-1}[/latex], the output resistance (in   [latex]k\Omega[/latex]) of the MOSFET is _________.
solution: Under channel length modulation, [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{D}&=I_{\text {Dsat }}\left(1+\lambda V_{\text {DS }}\right)\\ \frac{d I_{D}}{d V_{D S}} &=\frac{1}{r_{0}}=\lambda I_{\text {Dsat }} \\ r_{O} &=\frac{1}{\lambda I_{D \text { sat }}}=\frac{1}{0.05 \times 10^{-3}}=20 \mathrm{k} \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 The built-in potential of an abrupt p-n junction is 0.75 V. If its junction capacitance [latex](C_{J})[/latex] at a reverse bias [latex](V_{R})[/latex] of 1.25 V is 5 pF, the value of [latex]C_{J}[/latex] (in pF) when [latex]V_{R}[/latex] = 7.25 V is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{j} &\propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{V_{b i}+V_{R}}} \\ \frac{C_{2 j}}{C_{1 j}}&=\sqrt{\frac{V_{b i}+V_{R_{1}}}{V_{b i}+V_{R_{2}}}} \\ C_{2 j}&=C_{1 j} \sqrt{\frac{2}{8}}=\frac{C_{1 j}}{2}=2.5 \mathrm{pF} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, answer is 2.5

question: Question 89 A silicon sample is uniformly doped with donor type impurities with a concentration of [latex]10^{16} /cm^{3}[/latex]. The electron and hole mobilities in the sample are 1200 [latex]cm^{2}/V-s [/latex] and 400 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex]/V-s respectively. Assume complete ionization of impurities. The charge of an electron is [latex]1.6  \times 10^{-19}[/latex] C. The resistivity of the sample (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]-cm) is ____________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{\sigma_{N}}=\frac{1}{N_{D} q \mu_{n}} \\ &=\frac{1}{10^{16} \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 1200}=0.52 \Omega-\mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 An N -type semiconductor having uniform doping is biased as shown in the figure. If [latex]E_{C}[/latex] is the lowest energy level of the conduction band, [latex]E_{V}[/latex] is the highest energy level of the valance band and [latex]E_{F}[/latex] is the Fermi level, which one of the following represents the energy band diagram for the biased N -type semiconductor ?

Question 92 Consider two BJTs biased at the same collector current with area [latex]A_{1}=0.2\mu m \times 0.2\mu m [/latex] and [latex]A_{2}=300 \mu m \times 300 \mu m[/latex]. Assuming that all other device parameters are identical, kT/q = 26 mV, the intrinsic carrier concentration is [latex]1 \times 10^{10}cm^{-3},[/latex] and [latex] q=1.6 \times 10^{-19}C[/latex], the difference between the base-emitter
voltages (in mV) of the two BJTs (i.e.,[latex]V_{BE1}-V_{BE2}[/latex]) is _____.
solution: [latex]I_{C}[/latex] is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{C} &=I_{S} \exp \left[\frac{V_{B E}}{\eta V_{T}}\right] \\ I_{G} &=I_{S_{1}} \exp \left[\frac{V_{B E_{1}}}{\eta V_{T}}\right] &\ldots(i)\\ I_{C_{2}} &=I_{S_{2}} \exp \left[\frac{V_{B E_{2}}}{\eta V_{T}}\right]&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] According to given condition, [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{G}&= I_{C_{2}} \\ I_{S_{1}} \exp \left[\frac{V_{B E_{1}}}{\eta V_{T}}\right]&=I_{S_{2}} \exp \left[\frac{V_{B E_{2}}}{\eta V_{T}}\right] \\ V_{B E_{1}}-V_{B E_{2}} &=\eta V_{T} \ln \left[\frac{I_{S_{2}}}{I_{S_{1}}}\right] \\ V_{B E_{1}}-V_{B E_{2}} &=26 \ln \left[\frac{300 \times 300}{0.2 \times 0.2}\right]\\ \because \quad\eta&=2 for Si BJT\\ V_{B E_{1}}-V_{B E_{2}}&=380 .28 \mathrm{mV} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 93 Consider a silicon sample doped with [latex]N_{D}=1\times10^{15}/cm^{3}[/latex]
 donor atoms. Assume that the intrinsic carrier concentration [latex]n_{i}=1.5\times10^{10}/cm^{3}[/latex]. If the sample is additionally doped with [latex]N_{A}=1\times10^{18}/cm^{3}[/latex] acceptor atoms, the approximate number of electrons/[latex]cm^{3}[/latex]
 in the sample, at T = 300 K, will be _____.
solution: For a compensated p-type semiconductor, the minority carrier electron concentration is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} n_{0} &=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{\left(N_{A}-N_{D}\right)} \\ n_{0} &=\frac{2.25 \times 10^{20}}{\left(10^{18}-10^{15}\right)}=225.2 \mathrm{cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 97 An ideal MOS capacitor has boron doping-concentration of [latex]10^{15} cm ^{-3}[/latex] in the substrate.  When a gate voltage is applied, a depletion region of width 0.5 [latex]\mu[/latex]m is formed with a surface (channel) potential of 0.2 V. Given them is formed with a surface (channel) potential of 0.2 V.  Given the [latex]\varepsilon _{0}=8.854 \times 10^{-14}F/cm[/latex] and the relative permittivities of silicon and silicon
dioxide are 12 and 4, respectively, the peak electric field (in V/[latex]\mu[/latex]m) in the oxide region is _____.
solution: Peak electric field in the oxide region is [latex] \begin{aligned} E_{o x} &=\frac{E_{s}}{\epsilon_{o x}} E_{s} \\ \text{and}\quad E_{s} &=\frac{0.2 \times 2}{0.5}\\ E_{s}&=0.8 \mathrm{V} / \mu \mathrm{m}\\ \therefore \quad E_{o x} &=\frac{12}{4} \times 0.8 \\ E_{o x} &=2.4 \mathrm{V} / \mu \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 The slope of the [latex]I_{D}[/latex] vs. [latex]V_{GS}[/latex] curve of an n-channel MOSFET in linear regime is [latex]10^{-3}\Omega ^{-1}[/latex] at [latex]V_{DS}[/latex] = 0.1V. For the same device, neglecting channel length modulation, the slope of the [latex]\sqrt{I_{D}}[/latex] vs. [latex]V_{GS}[/latex] curve (in [latex]\sqrt{A}/V[/latex]) under saturation regime is approximately_____.
solution: We known that for linear region, [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{D} &=K_{n}\left[\left(V_{G S}-V_{t}\right) V_{D S}-\frac{V_{D S}^{2}}{2}\right] \\ \frac{\partial I_{D}}{\partial V_{G S}} &=K_{n} V_{D S}\\ \frac{10^{-3}}{0.1}&=K_{n} \\ \text{i.e.} \quad K_{n}&=10^{-2} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] and for saturation region [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{D} &=\frac{K_{n}}{2}\left(V_{G S}-V_{t}\right)^{2} \\ \sqrt{I_{D}} &=\sqrt{\frac{K_{n}}{2}}\left(V_{G S}-V_{t}\right) \\ \frac{\partial \sqrt{I_{D}}}{\partial V_{G S}} &=\sqrt{\frac{K_{n}}{2}}\\ \text{So }\quad\frac{\partial \sqrt{I_{D}}}{\partial V_{G S}}&=\sqrt{\frac{10^{-2}}{2}}=0.0707 \frac{\sqrt{A}}{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 99 The donor and accepter impurities in an abrupt junction silicon diode are [latex]1 \times 10^{16} cm^{-3} [/latex] and [latex] 5 \times 10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex], respectively. Assume that the intrinsic carrier concentration in silicon [latex]n_{i}=1.5 \times 10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex] at  300K, [latex]\frac{kT}{q}=26mV[/latex] and the permittivity of silicon [latex]\varepsilon_{st} =1.04 \times 12^{-12}F/cm[/latex]. The built-in potential and the
depletion width of the diode under thermal equilibrium conditions, respectively, are
solution: Built-in potential is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{b i}&=V_{T} \ln \left[\frac{N_{A} N_{D}}{n_{i}^{2}}\right] \\ V_{b i}&=0.026 \ln \left[\frac{10^{16} \times 5 \times 10^{18}}{2.25 \times 10^{20}}\right] \\ V_{b i}&=0.86 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] and depletion width W is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} W&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \epsilon}{q}\left[\frac{1}{N_{A}}+\frac{1}{N_{D}}\right] V_{b i}}\\ W&=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 1.04 \times 10^{-12}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}}\left[\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{18}}+\frac{1}{10^{16}}\right] \times 0.86} \\ W&=3.3 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 100 At T = 300 K, the hole mobility of a semiconductor [latex]\mu _{P}=500 cm^{2}/V-s [/latex] and [latex] \frac{KT}{q}=26mV[/latex]. The hole diffusion constant [latex]D_{P} \; in \; cm^{2}/s[/latex]  is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \frac{D_{p}}{\mu_{p}}=v_{T} \\ D_{p}=\mu_{p} V_{T}=500 \times 26 \times 10^{-3} \\ D_{p}=13 \mathrm{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 103 When a silicon diode having a doping concentration of [latex]N_{A}=9\times10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] on p
-side and [latex]N_{D}=1\times10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] on n-side is reverse biased, the total depletion width is found to be 3 [latex]\mu[/latex] m. Given that the permittivity of silicon is [latex]1.04\times10^{-12}[/latex] F/cm, the depletion width on the p-side and the maximum electric field in the depletion region, respectively, are
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{N_{A}}{N_{D}}&=\frac{x_{n}}{x_{p}}\\ So, \frac{N_{A}}{N_{D}}+1&=\frac{x_{n}}{x_{p}}+1 \\ \frac{N_{A}+N_{D}}{N_{D}}&=\frac{x_{n}+x_{p}}{x_{p}}\\ \frac{10^{17}}{10^{16}} &=\frac{3 \mu m}{x_{p}} \\ \therefore \quad x_{p} &=0.3 \mu \mathrm{m}\\ \text{and}\\ E_{\max }&=\frac{q N_{A} x_{p}}{\epsilon_{s}}=\frac{q N_{D} x_{n}}{\epsilon_{s}} \\ \therefore E_{\max } &=\frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 9 \times 10^{16} \times 0.3 \times 10^{-4}}{1.04 \times 10^{-12}} \\ E_{\max } &=4.15 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 104 Consider an abrupt PN junction (at T = 300 K) shown in the figure. The depletion
region width [latex]X_{n}[/latex] on the N -side of the junction is 0.2 [latex]\mu[/latex] m and the permittivity of
silicon ([latex]\varepsilon_{st}[/latex]) is [latex]1.044\times 10^{-12}[/latex] F/cm. At the junction, the approximate value of the peak electric field (in kV/cm) is_____.
solution: For abrupt [latex]P^{+}[/latex] N junction [latex] E_{\max }[/latex] is given: [latex] \begin{aligned} E_{\max } &=\frac{-q N_{0} x_{n}}{\epsilon_{s}}\qquad\left[\begin{array}{c} \because N_{A}>>N_{D} \\ W \simeq x_{n} \end{array}\right] \\ \Rightarrow E_{\max }&=\frac{-1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 10^{16} \times 0.2 \times 10^{-4}}{1.044 \times 10^{-12}} \\ E_{\max } &=-30.65 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{cm} \\ E_{\max } &=-30.65 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 Assume electronic charge [latex]q=1.6 \times 10^{-19}C[/latex], kT/q=25mV and electron mobility [latex]\mu _{n}=1000cm^{2} /V-s [/latex] . If the concentration gradient of electrons injected into a P-type silicon sample is [latex]1 \times 10^{21}/cm^{4}[/latex], the magnitude of electron diffusion current density (in [latex]A/cm^{2}[/latex]) is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} J &=q D_{n} \frac{d n}{d x} \\ \text { where, } D_{n} &=\mu_{n} V_{T} \\ D_{n} &=\frac{1000 \mathrm{cm}^{2}}{V s} \times 25 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{V} \\ D_{n} &=25 \mathrm{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text { then, } \quad J &=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 25 \times 1 \times 10^{21} \\ J &=4000 \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 A silicon bar is doped with donor impurities [latex]N_{D}=2.25\times10^{15} atom/cm^{3}[/latex]. Given the intrinsic carrier concentration of silicon at T = 300 K is [latex]n_{i}=1.5\times10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex]. Assuming complete impurity ionization, the equilibrium election and hole concentrations are
solution: since [latex]N_{D} \gt \gt n_{i}[/latex] therefore equilibrium electron  concentration is [latex] n \simeq N_{D}=2.25 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{cm}^{-3}[/latex] And equilibrium hole concentration is given by mass action law [latex] p=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{N_{D}}=\frac{\left(1.5 \times 10^{10}\right)^{2}}{2.25 \times 10^{15}}=1 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{cm}^{-3}[/latex]

question:
Question 108 A depletion type N-channel MOSFET is biased in its linear region for use as a
voltage controlled resistor. Assume threshold voltage [latex]V_{TH}=-0.5 V,V_{GS}=2.0 V [/latex], [latex]V_{DS}=5 V, W/L=100[/latex],[latex] C_{OX}=10^{-8} F/cm^{2}[/latex] and [latex]\mu _{n}=800 cm^{2}/V-s[/latex]. The value of the resistance of the voltage controlled resistor (in [latex]\Omega[/latex] ) is ______.
solution: Voltage controlled resistance [latex]r_{D S}[/latex] is is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{D S} &=\frac{1}{\left(\mu_{n} C_{o x}\right)\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)\left(V_{G S}-V_{t}\right)} \\ r_{D S} &=\frac{1}{800 \times 10^{-8} \times 100 \times(2+0.5)} \\ r_{D S} &=500 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 109 The doping concentrations on the p-side and n-side of a silicon diode are [latex]1\times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] and [latex]1 \times 10^{17}cm^{-3}[/latex], respectively. A forward bias of 0.3 V is applied to the diode. At T=300K, the
intrinsic carrier concentration of silicon [latex]n_{i}=1.5 \times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex] and [latex]\frac{KT}{q}=26mV[/latex]. The electron concentration at the edge of
the depletion region on the p-side is
solution: The electron concentration at the edge of the  depletion region on the p-side is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} n_{p} &=n_{p_{0}} \exp \left[\frac{q V_{t}}{k T}\right] \\ \text { where, } n_{p_{0}} &=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{N_{A}} \\ n_{p_{0}} &=\frac{\left(1.5 \times 10^{10}\right)^{2}}{10^{16}}=2.25 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{cm}^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] We then have [latex] \begin{array}{l} n_{p}=2.25 \times 10^{4} \exp \left[\frac{0.3}{0.026}\right]\\ n_{p}=2.25 \times 10^{4} \times 1.025 \times 10^{5} \\ n_{0}=2.306 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{cm}^{-3} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 110 A BJT is biased in forward active mode. Assume [latex]V_{BE}[/latex] = 0.7 V, kT/q = 25mV and reverse saturation current [latex]I_{S}=10^{-13} A[/latex]. The transconductance of the BJT (in mA/V) is _____.
solution: We know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} g_{m} &=\frac{I_{c}}{V_{T}} \\ \text{where}\quad I_{c} &=I_{s} e^{\frac{V_{B E}}{V_{T}}}\\ \text { So, } I_{c}&=10^{-13} \times e^{\frac{0.7}{0.025}} \\ I_{c}&=0.144 \mathrm{mA}\\ \text { Hence, }\quad g_{m}&=\frac{0.144}{0.025}=5.76 \mathrm{mAN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 115 In the three dimensional view of a silicon n-channel MOS transistor shown below, [latex]\delta[/latex]=20nm. The
transistor is of width 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]m. The depletion width formed at every p-n junction is 10 nm. The relative
permittivities of Si and [latex]SiO_{2}[/latex], respectively, are 11.7 and 3.9, and [latex]\varepsilon _{0}=8.9\times 10^{-12}[/latex] F/m. The source-body junction capacitance is approximately
solution: Source body junction capacitor, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{j}&=\frac{\in A}{d}=\frac{\epsilon_{0} \in_{T} A}{d}\\ \text{here, }\quad \epsilon_{r}&=11.7 \text{ as there is Si only y }\\ A&=1 \mu \mathrm{m} \times 0.2 \mu \mathrm{m}=0.2 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ d&= \text{depletion width of p-n junction}\\ d&=10 \mathrm{nm}=10^{-8} \mathrm{m} \\ \text{So,}\quad C_{j}&=\frac{8.9 \times 10^{-12} \times 11.7 \times 0.2 \times 10^{-12}}{10^{-8}}\\ C_{j}&=2.082 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{F} \\ C_{j} &\cong 2 \mathrm{pF} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 116 In the three dimensional view of a silicon n-channel MOS transistor shown below, [latex]\delta[/latex]=20nm. The
transistor is of width 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]m. The depletion width formed at every p-n junction is 10 nm. The relative
permittivities of Si and [latex]SiO_{2}[/latex], respectively, are 11.7 and 3.9, and [latex]\varepsilon _{0}=8.9\times 10^{-12}[/latex] F/m. The gate-source overlap capacitance is approximately
solution: Gate source capacitance [latex]C_{g}[/latex] is [latex] C_{g}=\frac{\epsilon_{1} A_{1}}{d_{1}}=\frac{\epsilon_{0} \in_{r 1} A_{1}}{d_{1}}[/latex] [latex] \epsilon_{r 1}=3.9 [/latex] as between gate and source there is [latex] \mathrm{SiO}_{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} &=1 \mu m \times \delta=1 \times 10^{-6} \times 20 \times 10^{-9} \\ &=2 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ d_{1} &=1 \mathrm{nm}=10^{-9} \mathrm{m}\\ So. C_{g}&=\frac{8.9 \times 10^{-12} \times 3.9 \times 2 \times 10^{-14}}{10^{-9}} \\ C_{g}&=69.42 \times 10^{-17} \mathrm{F} \\ C_{g}&=0.69 \times 10^{-15} \\ C_{g}&=0.7 \mathrm{pF} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 117 The source of a silicon ([latex]n_{i} = 10^{10} [/latex]per [latex]cm^{3}[/latex]) n-channel MOS transistor has an area of 1 sq [latex]\mu[/latex]m and a depth of 1 [latex]\mu[/latex]m. If the dopant density in the source is [latex]10^{19}/cm^{3}[/latex], the number of holes in the source

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} n_{i} &=10^{10} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ A &=1 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ d &=10^{-6} \mathrm{m} \\ V &=A d=10^{-18} \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ &=10^{-12} \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ N_{D} &=n=10^{19} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ p &=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{N_{D}}=\frac{10^{20}}{10^{19}}=10 / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, holes in volume V is [latex] H=p V=10^{-11} [/latex] since, holes number can not be a decimal number so H=0

question: Question 118 The i-v characteristics of the diode in the circuit given below are [latex]i=\left\{\begin{matrix} \frac{v-0.7}{500}A &v\geq 0.7V \\ 0 A & v \lt 0.7 V \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The current in the circuit is
solution: Applying KVL in given circuit we have [latex] 10-1000 i-v=0 \qquad\ldots(1)[/latex] since 10 V is greater than 0.7 V so current will flow through diode and is [latex] i=\frac{v-0.7}{500}\qquad\ldots(2)[/latex] from (1) and (2) we have, [latex] \begin{aligned} 10-2(v-0.7)-v &=0 \\ 10+1.4-3 v &=0 \\ 3 v &=11.4 \\ v &=\frac{11.4}{3}=3.8 v\\ \text{so}\quad i &=\frac{v-0.7}{500}=\frac{3.8-0.7}{500} \\ &=6.2 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 119 The channel resistance of an N-channel JFET shown in the figure below is 600 [latex]\Omega[/latex] when the full channel thickness ([latex]t_{ch}[/latex]) of 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex] is available for conduction. The
built-in voltage of the gate [latex]P^+ N[/latex] junction ([latex]V_{bi}[/latex]) is -1 V. When the gate to source
voltage ([latex]V_{GS}[/latex]) is 0 V, the channel is depleted by 1 [latex]\mu m[/latex] on each side due to the builtin voltage and hence the thickness available for conduction is only 8 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. The channel resistance when [latex]V_{GS}[/latex] =0 V is
solution: Depletion layer width [latex] \begin{aligned} w &\propto \sqrt{V_{G S}+V_{b i}}\\ \text { Given, } & V_{b i}=-1 \\ \text { and for, } & V_{G S}=0 \mathrm{V}, w_{1}=1 \mu \mathrm{m}\\ \text{Now for, }\quad V_{G S}&=-3 \mathrm{V}, w_{2} \text{ can be calculated}\\ \text{as }\quad \frac{w_{1}}{w_{2}}&=\sqrt{\frac{0-1}{-3-1}}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad w_{2}&=2 \mu m \\ \end{aligned} [/latex] Channel width [latex]\uparrow \Rightarrow[/latex] channel resistance [latex]\uparrow [/latex] For [latex]10 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex] channel resistance [latex]=600 \Omega [/latex] For [latex]8 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex] channel resistance [latex] =\frac{600 \times 100}{8}=750 \Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 121 For a BJT the common base current gain [latex]\alpha[/latex] = 0.98 and the collector base
junction reverse bias saturation current [latex]I_{CO} = 0.6 \mu A[/latex]. This BJT is connected in the common emitter mode and operated in the active region with a base drive

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{C} &=\beta I_{B}+(1+\beta) I_{C O} \\ \beta &=\frac{\alpha}{1-\alpha}=\frac{0.98}{1-0.98}=49 \\ I_{C}&=49 \times 20+50 \times 0.6 \\ \therefore \quad &=980+30=1010 \mu \mathrm{A} \\ \text{or}\quad I_{C}&=1.01 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]
