Question 137 The cross section of a JFET is shown in the following figure. Let [latex]V_{G}[/latex] be -2V and let [latex]V_{P}[/latex] be the initial pinch -off voltage. If the width W is doubled (with
other geometrical parameters and doping levels remaining the same), then the
ratio between the mutual trans conductances of the initial and the modified
JFET is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} g_{m} &=g_{m 0}\left[1-\left(\frac{-V_{G}}{V_{P}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\right] \\ \text { where, } g_{m o} &=\frac{2 a z}{\rho L} \end{aligned}[/latex] a [latex]\rightarrow [/latex] Half channel height L [latex]\rightarrow [/latex] Length of channel z [latex]\rightarrow [/latex] Depth of channel [latex]\rho \rightarrow [/latex] Resistivity of channel since all the parameters are same except width 'W'. So. [latex] \begin{aligned} W &\propto a\\ \therefore \quad g_{m 0}&=\frac{2 W z}{\rho L} \\ g_{m}&=g_{m o}\left[1-\left(-\frac{V_{G}}{V_{p}}\right)^{1 / 2}\right] \\ g_{\text {initial }}&=W\left[1-\left(-\frac{V_{G_{1}}}{V_{P_{1}}}\right)^{1 / 2}\right] &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, the width is doubled. So, [latex] \begin{aligned} g_{\text {mmodifed}}&=2 W\left[1-\left(-\frac{V_{G_{1}}}{4 V_{P_{1}}}\right)^{1 / 2}\right] &\ldots(ii)\\ &\qquad \left[\because V_{p}=\frac{q N_{0} a^{2}}{2 \epsilon}\right] \\ \frac{g_{\text {mmodifes }}}{g_{\text {minitial }}}&=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{1-\sqrt{\frac{2}{V_{p}}}}{1-\sqrt{\frac{1}{2 V_{p}}}}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 138 Silicon is doped with boron to a concentration of [latex]4 \times 10^{17}[/latex] atoms/ [latex]cm^{3}[/latex]. Assume the intrinsic carrier concentration of silicon to be  [latex]1.5 \times 10^{10}/cm^{3}[/latex] and the value of kT/q to be 25 mV at 300 K. Compared to undopped silicon, the fermi level of doped silicon
solution: Since, boron is p-type impurity, therefore, fermi level goes down [latex] \begin{aligned} E_{i}-E_{f} &=k T \ln \frac{N_{A}}{n_{i}} \\ &=25 \times 10^{-3} \ln \frac{4 \times 10^{17}}{1.5 \times 10^{10}}=0.427 \mathrm{eV} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 The measured trans conductance [latex]g_{m}[/latex] of an NMOS transistor operating in the linear region is plotted against the gate voltage [latex]V_{G}[/latex] at a constant drain voltage [latex]V_{D}[/latex]. Which of the following figures represents the expected dependence of [latex]g_{m}[/latex] on [latex]V_{G}[/latex] ?
solution: [latex]I_{D}[/latex] is given by, [latex] I_{D}=K_{n}\left[\left(V_{g s}-V_{t}\right) V_{D S}-\frac{V_{D S}^{2}}{2}\right]- [/latex]inlinear region [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{and }g_{m}&=\frac{\partial I_{D}}{\partial V_{g S}} \text{ at constant }V_{D S} \\ g_{m}&=\frac{\partial I_{D}}{\partial V_{g s}}=K_{n}\left(V_{G S}-V_{t}\right) V_{D S} \\ \therefore g_{m} &\propto V_{G S} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, linear relation.

question: Question 140 The drain current of MOSFET in saturation is given by [latex]I_{D}=K(V_{GS}-V_{T})^{2}[/latex] where K is a constant. The magnitude of the transconductance [latex]g_{m}[/latex] is

Question 145 The figure shows the high-frequency capacitance-voltage (C-V) characteristics of a Metal/[latex]SiO_2[/latex]/silicon (MOS) capacitor having an area of [latex]1\times 10^{-4}cm^{2}[/latex]
 Assume that the permittivities ([latex]\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon _{r}[/latex]) of silicon and SiO2 are  [latex]1\times 10^{-12}[/latex] F/cm and [latex]3.5\times 10^{-13}[/latex]
F/cm respectively. The maximum depletion layer width in silicon is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \epsilon_{s i} &=10^{-12} \mathrm{F} / \mathrm{cm} \\ &=10^{-10} \mathrm{F} / \mathrm{m} \\ C_{\min } &=\frac{C_{\max } \cdot C_{d}}{C_{\max }+C_{d}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad C_{d} &=\frac{C_{\max } \cdot C_{\min }}{C_{\max }-C_{\min }} \\ C_{d} &=\frac{7 \times 1}{7-1}=1.166 \mathrm{pF} \\ C_{d} &=\frac{\epsilon_{s i} \cdot A}{w} \\ \Rightarrow \quad w&=\frac{10^{-10} \times 10^{-4} \times 10^{-4}}{1.166 \times 10^{-12}}=0.857 \mu \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

F/cm respectively. The gate oxide thickness in the MOS capacitor is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C&=\frac{\varepsilon A}{d} \\ d&=\frac{\varepsilon A}{C}=\frac{3.5 \times 10^{-13} \times 1 \times 10^{-4} \times 10^{-4}}{7 \times 10^{-12} \times 10^{-2}}\\ &= 5 x 10^{-8} m = 50 nm \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Junction potential = Built-in potential + reverse bias voltage [latex] V_{j}=V_{0}+V_{R}[/latex] Now for abrupt pn-junction depletion width [latex] \begin{aligned} W &\propto V_{j}^{1 / 2} \\ W&=K V_{j}^{1 / 2} \\ 2 \mu m&=K(0.8+1.2)^{1 / 2} &\ldots(i)\\ x&=K(0.8+7.2)^{1 / 2} &\ldots(ii)\\ \text{From (i) \& (ii)} x&=4 \mu \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 151 The electron and hole concentrations in an intrinsic semiconductor are [latex]n_{i}[/latex] per [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] at 300 K. Now, if acceptor impurities are introduced with a concentration
of [latex]N_{A}[/latex] per [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] (where [latex]N_{A}\gt \gt n_{i}[/latex]  ), the electron concentration per [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] at 300 K
will be
solution: By the law of electrical neutrality [latex] \begin{aligned} p+N_{0} &=n+N_{A} \\ \text{as}\quad\quad N_{0} &=0\\ N_{A}&>>n_{i} \cong 0 \quad p=N_{A}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] using mass action law [latex]\mathrm{np}=n_{i}^{2}[/latex] So. [latex]\quad n=\frac{n_{i}^{2}}{p}=\frac{n_i^{2}}{N_{A}}[/latex]

question:
Question 152 A heavily doped n-type semiconductor has the following data: Hole-electron ratio :0.4 Doping concentration : [latex] 4.2 \times 10^{8}[/latex] atoms/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] Intrinsic concentration :[latex] 1.5 \times 10^{4}[/latex] atoms/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] The ratio of conductance of the n-type semiconductor to that of the intrinsic
semiconductor of same material and ate same temperature is given by
solution: For n-type semiconductor [latex]\sigma_{n}=n q \mu_{n} [/latex] For intrinsic semiconductor, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{i} &=n_{i} q\left(\mu_{n}+\mu_{p}\right) \\ \frac{\sigma_{n}}{\sigma_{i}} &=\frac{n \mu_{n}}{n_{i}\left(\mu_{n}+\mu_{p}\right)} \\ &=\frac{4.2 \times 10^{8} \times \mu_{n}}{1.5 \times 10^{4} \times \mu_{n}\left(1+\frac{\mu_{p}}{\mu_{n}}\right)} \\ &=\frac{4.2 \times 10^{8}}{1.5 \times 10^{4} \times 1.4}=2 \times 10^{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 170 Consider an abrupt p-n junction. Let [latex]V_{bi}[/latex] be the built-in potential of this junction and [latex]V_R[/latex] be the applied reverse bias. If the junction capacitance ([latex]C_{1}[/latex]) is 1 pF for [latex]V_{bi}+V_{R}[/latex]=1V, then for [latex]V_{bi}+V_{R}[/latex]=4V, [latex]C_{j}[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{j} & \propto V_{i}^{-1 / 2} \\ \frac{C_{i 2}}{C_{i_{1}}} &=\sqrt{\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{4}}=\frac{1}{2} \\ C_{i_{2}} &=\frac{C_{h}}{2}=\frac{1 \mathrm{pF}}{2}=0.5 \mathrm{pF} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 171 The resistivity of a uniformly doped n-type silicon sample is 0.5[latex]\Omega[/latex] - mc. If the electron mobility ([latex]\mu_{n}[/latex]) is 1250 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex]/V-sec and the charge of an electron is [latex]1.6\times 10^{-19}[/latex] Coulomb, the donor impurity concentration ([latex]N_{D}[/latex]) in the sample is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho &=\frac{1}{n q \mu_{n}} \\ n &=N_{D} \\ N_{D} &=\frac{1}{q \mu_{n} \rho}=\frac{1}{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 1250 \times 0.5} \\ &=10^{16} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 172 In an abrupt p-n junction, the doping concentrations on the p-side and n-side are [latex]N_{A}=9\times 10^{16}/cm^{3}[/latex] and [latex]N_{D}=1\times 10^{16}/cm^{3}[/latex] respectively. The p-n junction is reverse biased
and the total depletion width is 3 [latex]\mu[/latex]m. The depletion width on the p-side is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\omega_{n}}{\omega_{p}}&=\frac{N_{A}}{N_{D}} \qquad \omega \simeq \omega_{n} \quad\left(\because \omega_{n}\gt \gt \omega_{p}\right) \\ \omega_{p}&=\frac{\omega_{n} \times N_{D}}{N_{A}}=\frac{3 \mu m \times 10^{16}}{9 \times 10^{16}}=0.3 \mu \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 177 When the gate-to-source voltage ([latex]V_{Gs}[/latex]) of a MOSFET with threshold voltage of 400 mV, working in saturation is 900 mV, the drain current is observed to be 1 mA. Neglecting the channel width modulation effect and assuming that the MOSFET is operating at saturation, the drain current for an applied [latex]V_{Gs}[/latex] of 1400 mV is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{D} &=K\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ 1 \mathrm{mA} &=K(900-400)^{2} \\ K &=\frac{1 \mathrm{mA} / \mathrm{V}^{2}}{10^{4} \times 25} \\ \text { When } V_{G S} &=1400 \mathrm{V} \\ I_{D} &=K\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2}\\ &=\frac{1 \mathrm{mA}}{25 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{V}^{2}}(1400-400)^{2} \mathrm{V}^{2} \\ &=\frac{1 \mathrm{mA} \times 100}{25 \times 10^{4}} \times 10^{4} \\ I_{D} &=4 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{g} &=\frac{1.24}{\lambda(\mu \mathrm{m})} \mathrm{eV} \\ &=\frac{1.24}{5490 \times 10^{-4} \mu \mathrm{m}}=2.26 \mathrm{eV} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 179 At 300 K, for a diode current of 1 mA, a certain germanium diode requires a forward bias of 0.1435 V, whereas a certain silicon diode requires a forward bias of 0.718 V. Under the conditions state above, the closest approximation of the ratio of reverse saturation current in germanium diode to that in silicon diode is
solution: [latex]\eta=1 [/latex] for Germanium [latex] \eta=2 [/latex] for Silicon at low value of current [latex] \begin{aligned} I&=I_{O S i}\left(e^{\frac{V_{D 1}}{\eta V_{T}}}-1\right) &\ldots(i)\\ I&=I_{O G e}\left(e^{\frac{V_{D 2}}{\eta V_{T}}}-1\right)&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] L.H.S. of (i) = (ii) [latex] \Rightarrow I_{O_{S i}}\left(e^{\frac{V_{D 1}}{\eta V_{T}}}-1\right)=I_{O_{G e}}\left(e^{\frac{V_{D 2}}{\eta V_{T}}}-1\right) [/latex] [latex] \frac{I_{O_{Ge}}}{I_{O_{Si}}}=\frac{e^{\frac{V_{D_{1}}}{\eta V_{T}}}-1}{e^{\frac{V_{D_{2}}}{\eta V_{T}}}-1}=\frac{e^{\frac{0.718}{2 \times 26 \times 10^{-3}}}-1}{e^{\frac{0.1435}{26 \times 10^{-3}}}-1}=4 \times 10^{3}[/latex]

question: Question 189 The effective channel length of a MOSFET in saturation decreases with increase in
solution: At the edge of saturation i.e. when drain to source voltage reaches [latex]V_{D_{sat}}[/latex] the inversion layer charge at the drain end becomes zero (ideally). The channel is said to be pinched off at the drain end. If the drain to source voltage [latex]V_{DS}[/latex] is increased even further beyond the saturation edge so that [latex]V_{DS} \gt V_{D_{sat}}[/latex], an even larger  portion of the channel becomes pinched off and effective channel length is reduced.
